Problem:
Consider a system where the temperature distribution along a rod is governed by the heat equation \\( u_t = ku_{xx} \\) where k is a positive constant. We examine the effects of introducing a boundary condition modified at \\( x = 0 \\) over time t, such as \\( u(0,t) = u(0,t)e^{\\alpha t} \\), where \\( \\alpha \\) is a constant.

If the initial temperature distribution \\( u(x,0) = u_0(x) \\) is modified to \\( u_0(x)e^{\\alpha t} \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\( u_t = ku_{xx} \\) without further intervention, will the temperature distribution \\( u(x,T) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( u_0(x) \\) evolved to t = T under \\( u_t = ku_{xx} \\) alone?
Explanation: Modifying the boundary condition alters the initial conditions at the boundary, influencing the solution of the heat equation across the domain. The exponential factor \\( e^{\\alpha t} \\) affects how the boundary condition evolves over time, leading to a different temperature distribution at any time T.
